So the theme of my forgotten journal is going to change quite quickly here.  I am in need of a place to record my thoughts and my memories.  Not too long ago, Dane and I spent a few hours going over some of my journal entries here.  We laughed and joked and talked about things we had completely forgotten.  It was nice to have those memories written down, because obviously my brain had found a way to push them back into Neverland.  Now more than ever, there is a place in my life I want to remember every single moment.

I met Dane about 15 months ago.  We met through the internet on Match.com.  Yes, I tend not to tell people this all the time, but the truth remains the same.  We started talking in August and decided to meet in September.  Hurricane Rita tried to ruin our plans, but in the end we prevailed.  He "sheltered" with my mom, her boyfriend, my sister, and some random guy my mom's boyfriend knew for 2 nights.  We were stuck together for 2 days and 2 nights and we got along perfectly.  We spent time getting to know each other in our pj's because we had no electricity.  We played silly card and trivia games with my family and essentially we started on this journey.

Over the past year, we moved in to our own apartment in December between Christmas and New Year's and continued to fall in love.  Actually by this time we were both pretty sure we had found "the one."  Of course, we disagreed and we had to learn to communicate and work through difference of opinion, but at the end of the day we were still happy and secure with the knowledge that what we had was greater than any disagreement.  In September, we decided to start looking for our first house.  On the first afternoon, we found it.  It is perfect.  We put an offer down on Sunday, which was accepted and a mere 40 days later signed on the dotted line.  We had our first home, a beautiful 3 bedroom-2 bathroom house built in 1947, and updated recently.  We moved on November 3rd and spent most of November unpacking and learning the joys and pains of being homeowners.

Fast forward to December 2006.  Friday night, December 1st, we had date night.  We went to Maggiano's and split a bottle of wine and had a wonderful romantic dinner.  It was great, something we should do much more often.  Saturday was spent watching football and decorating for Christmas.  Dane had some work to do for a big proposal due this week and I just enjoyed a lazy, cold Saturday afternoon.  We had a Christmas party to attend Saturday night hosted by some of Dane's college friends.  We both got dressed up in our holiday gear and decided to head our to the party.  

Dane, however, had a few other plans.  As we were standing in the living room talking he mentioned that the plant my mother had given us (daisies, geraniums, chysanthemums) as a house-warming gift was beginning to die.  He picked a small bloom off the floor and said, "Look at this one, he fell on the floor."  He then handed me the flower and picked one petal off saying "She loves me." I responded with "Yes, I do."  He then asked me to finish the childhood saying we are all familiar with.  As I made my way through the petals he just sat there smiling.  As I pulled the last petal I spoke, "She loves me not."  I then began to make as many excuses as I could about why this was not true.  I tried to tell him the stem counted as "She loves me" or that it was really "She loves me or She loves me alot."  He wasn't buying it.

He just sat and smiled and then said, "I think you need another petal"  which I agreed with.  Before I knew it out of his pocket came a beautiful wooden box, small enough that my brain started to register exactly what was happening.  I started to open the box and he bent on one knee.  Inside was the most beautiful engagement ring  I had ever seen and kneeling before me was the most honest, remarkable, wonderful man I had ever met.  Tied around the band was the last "She loves me" petal.  He looked at me with tears in his eyes and spoke the words we all dream of hearing, "Amy, will you marry me?"  I couldn't talk or move, I  just stood there speechless for a good 30 seconds.  I then grabbed him in a huge hug and laughed and cried all at one time.  It was perfect and of course, I said YES!  

We spent the next few moments in complete bliss, laughing and crying and kissing and putting on my ring and telling each other how much we loved each other.  It was absolutely perfect...I couldn't have imagined it any other way.  Little to say, we didn't make the Christmas party.  We called his parents, who were ecstatic and then we made our way to my mom's house to tell her the good news.

His dad wears his mom's dad's ring (Dane's maternal grandfather's) which he inherited after Gus died.  He asked Dane if he would do him the honor of wearing his ring as his wedding ring.  I have no idea if that made any sense, but basically Dane is going to wear his dad's wedding band.

I spend the rest of the night in complete euphoria.  I honestly don't remember if I truly heard him "pop" the question.    When I saw the box and him getting on one knee I lost it.  I saw the rest of my life unfolding in front of me, and I couldn't have been happier. 

We spent Sunday in relative seclusion, calling some close family and friends, but mainly just together.  For him, it is something that for a long time he never believed he would find.  For me, it was something I had always dreamed of finally becoming a reality.  

The word fiance seems a little weird, the words husband and wife seems to flow much more smoothly.  The words bride and groom are still rather foreign in my vocabulary.  Today at work it was exciting to tell the story and show off my ring.  I spend most of the day making sure it hadn't gone anywhere.

We have both agreed that the wedding will sometime next fall probably October or November.  We aren't in any hurry to start planning and right now we are just relishing in the engagement euphoria.  I will scan the websites over the next few weeks but don't plan on doing any serious planning until January.  Right now, I am just extremely happy and yes, in love.  I have truly found my best friend and couldn't be happier knowing that soon I will be his wife.

I am sitting here feeling rather lost right now...
A million thoughts are running through my mind and each time I try to reach up and grab one my hand blurs the waters and I have to start over again...
None of my thoughts amount to much at the moment, just a mixture of self-doubt, denial, anger, fear, unrest, and failures run through my mind like a freight train entering a long, dark tunnel...the end not quite insight, but there, in the back of my mind...
Oh what kind of monster will I be...
Oh what kind of monster will I be...

Hello LJ world.  Yes, once again it has been too long.  

Thankfully my life has remained good.  I am now residing more with the boy in Houston than with my mom. It always requires a little adjustment, but he is great and has made it pretty easy.  I love going home to him every night, but even better is waking up with him in the morning.  I love just sitting in bed still trying to shake off the sleep and talking.  We have the most random conversations, but I love them and they make me so happy.  They help start off my days even better than I could have ever thought.

Last night I got to see BON JOVI though, and that too was awesome.  He has such a great tush and is still so damn sexy!!!!  The concert was awesome and I sang my heart out to the classics and some of the new ones.  I was probably one of the youngest ones there though which was quite interesting.  The people around us were 50 and 60 year old men and women dressed out in lighted T-shirts and last years leather pants.  Oh how I wish I had a camera phone.  It was a great night, even though it made for a very early morning.

Lastly, I want to express my condolences to Nick and his family on the loss of his cousin.  I don't have any experience personally with addiction or suicide in my family.  Nonetheless, I love Nick and have tried to the best of my ability to educate myself on his disease.  I am greatly sorry for his loss, but extremely thankful for his life.

Well hello there again LJ...it has been too long....no really, it is all my fault...I should have been a better friend...you forgive me, good....I'd hoped you would.

Okay, apologies over.  Yes, I am posting....finally.

Maybe what they say is true, when life is pretty good and things are rolling your way, it is better to stay quiet then tempt the gods to give you something to write about (or in other words bitch about).  By far my life is great, no complaints here.  I have awesome friends, a great family who loves me no matter what, and a fabulous man who wraps me in his arms every night. What else could a girl ask for?  Truly not much.  I am learning slowly but surely to adjust to life...not questioning everything just living.  It is easier but still far away from being normal.

I was rereading some of my earlier posts this evening, and I amazed at how much time changes things.  There were definitely posts that still today bring tears to my eyes, because I can remember that day and that emotion.  The raw hurt of a relationship when you begin to realize that it was never going to work, or the true terror in leaving the place I found myself to travel 1500 miles away and begin again.  There were also the happy posts, the posts where dreams became reality and that little girl began to trust herself.  No wonder keeping a journal is therapeutic.  It allows you the travel back to the best and worst of times, it allows you to remember and value the lessons learned.

I can't believe it is already the middle of January.  As age increases, time does decrease.  5 days from now will be the 1 year anniversary of my grandfather's (I called him Papa) death.  The first death I had experienced as an adult...the first realization that sometimes hurt doesn't go away it just dulls with time.  My grandparents were married just 5 days short of 60 years.  SIXTY YEARS.  I still can't comprehend that number, that dedication, and that love.  They met when she was still a teenager and he was just a few years older.  They courted and dated and then he left for WWII.  They wrote letters back and forth and she prayed he would make it home safe and she loved him the best she could for such a young girl.  He came back and they married and eventually had two children.  They were frugal or better put he was frugal.  A great example is that before they had kids he took the backseat out of their car to use as their living room sofa.  He never finished high school, but worked hard as a master plumber and died not owing a penny to a soul.  He paid for everything in cash...his house, his car, his trips.  If they didn't have the money, then they didn't need whatever it was.

I loved my Papa.  He was such a great man...he loved me.  He was proud of me.  He had the greatest hugs.  Last Christmas was the last time I ever saw him.  I was home from Philadelphia and the entire family came over to our house.  We had dinner and opened presents and talked and took pictures.  Family pictures, pictures that show he lived and that he was loved.  If I had only known I would have spent more time just talking to him and hugging him, but of course no one had a clue.  He wasn't sick or frail, just elderly.  My aunt, uncle, cousins, and grandparents left late that night.  I don't even remember telling him "Goodbye, or I love you."  I just remember that all of a sudden he was no longer there.  I flew back to Philly taking for granted that I would see him the next time I came home for a visit.

He went into the hospital on January 10th with what he thought was a heart attack. It wasn't.  It was a gallbladder attack.  He was there for tests and lots of other stuff, and finally had his gallbladder removed.  I talked with him and the rest of my family frequently, but never understood the severity of the situation.  My family is not medically oriented, except for me.  They had hope that all would be okay, and in the end it gave me hope as well.  The day he was supposed to get discharged he got an infection.  It spread fast, and before I knew it he was in the ICU.  The next morning his heart stopped beating...they brought him back.  My sisters called me in Philly and I got the first flight out...it wasn't until Saturday morning.  They shocked him 13 times to get his heart back, he was now on life support.  My sisters saw him and told him goodbye and how much they loved him.  My mom and her brother said goodbye.  They all tell me he was already gone, he died that morning, and only modern technology brought him back.  Later that morning my grandmother was visiting and his heart stopped beating again.  The nurses and doctors ran in and started CPR...my grandmother stopped them and asked them to leave.  She then crawled in bed with him and held him as he died.  She didn't want him to live like this, she didn't want him to suffer.  She held him and kissed his cheek as he slipped out of this world.  My sisters called me about 15 minutes after it happened.  I wasn't there...I didn't get to say goodbye.  It still haunts me to this day.  I know that he knew how much I loved him, but I would have loved to say it just one more time.  I would love one more hug.

I got there the next day, and stayed with my Nana (that is what I call my grandmother) while my mom and sisters went home.  We talked until late in the night on Saturday...about a million different things.  She would periodically cry and then wipe her eyes and go on with whatever she was saying.  We opened a bottle of wine and just talked.  It will forever be one of my favorite memories.  Right before we went to bed, she started crying again.  This time she couldn't stop and I just held her.  Finally, she said she needed to ask me a question.  "Do you think your Papa is angry that I let him die?"  That was the question.  And my reply was, "Absolutely not.  I think Papa is so proud of you right now.  You let him go where he could take care of you again.  He is so happy you loved him enough to let him go."  We were both crying now, and she replied, "It was my last gift of love to him, to let him go in peace with me by his side."

So as I sit here and cry while typing this into the computer, I remeber how lucky I am to have been loved by this man.  He would write my Nana poems for every occassion.  She has them for 60+ years, letters from the war, and love poems to showcase their love.  She won't let us see them...she tells me when she is no longer here I can have them and read them and learn a little more about a very special love...until then she likes knowing that she is the only one who truly understands.

We laid my Papa to rest on Tuesday, I think.  I can't truly remember.  I know there are people who read this who don't necessarily believe in God...but the love my grandparents had for each other transcended Heaven and Earth.  My Nana always got white roses from my Papa for special celebrations...anniversaries, birthdays, just because.  She received a huge ivy plant from the lady who came weekly to help them take care of their house.  She placed 12 red silk roses within the ivy.  It was beautiful and my Nana truly treasured the plant.  On the day of their 60th Anniversary she went to  the cemetary to bring him some roses and cry...when she got home all 12 of the red silk roses had opened to full bloom.  I have no explanation for it and neither did she.  To her and to me though it was the sign that she needed to go on living...he was there, he didn't forget, and she still got her roses.

The white man fainted and fell to the floor. The big guy knelt down and
brought him to by shaking him. The big guy said, "What's wrong with you?"
In a weak voice the little guy said, "What EXACTLY did you say to me?"

The big dude said, "I saw your curious look and figured I'd just give you
the answers to the questions everyone always asks me. I'm 7 feet tall, I

around'!"

Well, yes, it has been a long time I know. It just seems like I could come up with 1000 reasons why I don't ever have any time to post, but, honestly, the truth is sometimes I am just too damn LAZY.  I come home from work and by the time I really think about posting I would rather curl up in my bed with a good book, read a little, and then off to sleep.  I am going to try and do better, I hope...just be patient, please.

Work is good.  I had 3 cases today and they all went well.  I am finally beginning to feel comfortable in this OR. It takes a while to understand who you can trust and who you can't, as well as, who understands your jokes and others who still haven't completely accepted the fact that women are actually doctors and surgeons, too.  I worked really closely with some vascular surgeons while in residency, and learned a lot from them.  We had a guy from a vascular company come to our office the other day and give us a presentation on their products.  I asked lots of questions, and before I knew it we had discussed some procedures in quite detail.  I guess they liked my interest, because 1 week later they called and asked if I wanted to attend a conference in Las Vegas this weekend.  And, of course, I said YES!!

We (Dane and I) leave on Thursday afternoon and take the redeye back on Saturday night.  He has never been and is soooo excited...its pretty cute.  I have been 2X, but not in the last 5 years.  We are staying at a non-gaming hotel (I didn't know these existed in Vegas), which is good on quite a few levels.  First, the rooms or hotel won't smell like smoke...no old geezers walking around with their oxygen tanks in one hand and their cigs in the other.  Second, it is at the end of the strip right by Mandalay Bay...so a great location.  Third, and most importantly, is the fact that there is no gambling in the hotel.  I haven't been to a casino since the ex-BF and I broke up over 3 years ago.  He had a gambling problem and I got roped in as well.  We gambled all the time and I racked up some pretty substantial debt that I have been paying for over the past 3 years.  I haven't gone into a casino since then.  I figured if I didn't tempt myself then I could fall back into the same practices.  Well, I feel pretty good about this trip.  I am not going to think I won't go and gamble a little bit, but I am going to set myself a limit and stick to it.  

Here is the question though...Is this similar to any addiction and by me saying I will only gamble a little bit really is the same thing as I am going to have only 1 drink?  What happens if I go and once again this strange feeling of not being able to stop takes over again.  I have more money to blow, but that is definitely not a good thing.  I am hoping that most of the gambling came from the fact that the ex and I didn't get along all that well towards the end.  One of the only things we enjoyed doing together was gambling.  I think sometimes I went along only because it meant we could spend time together not fighting.  what do you think?  Am I setting myself up for failure?

One other good thing is that Dane doesn't gamble much at all.  He is much more interested in seeing the sites and visiting the other casinos and not the gambling aspect of Vegas.  I guess we shall see.  Does it help that I at least realize that I had a problem and am aware that I must be careful while on vacation???

Anyway, hopefully I can post again before I leave, but don't hold your breath.

(And for those of you who know me, you already know that I have had about 2 glasses too many) I have decided it is time for an update into the ever-changing life of ME. First let me qualify the statement made above...I did not sleep last night...I tossed and turned and tossed and turned and got up to walk around and shower and still NO SLEEP...I finally fell asleep around 3 am and had to be up at 6:30 am to get ready for work. Whether it is right or not I am trying to ensure I at least get 5 hours tonight.

Now onto more interesting and exciting stuff...

I have truly met an amazing person...someone who makes me laugh and smile...someone who allows me to just be me...someone, who for the first time in a long time, I don't have to worry about...someone who has made me feel extremely lucky...

Thursday night I received a call from Dane who excitedly told me he had won tickets on eBay for the Alabama-LSU game in Tuscaloosa this weekend.  Dane is a die-hard LSU fan.  He was born and raised in New Orleans and has basically been a Tiger for his entire life, everyone in his family loves LSU, even the cat.  He had been sporadically talking about possibly trying to get to this game, but I thought it was more whim than reality.  Hello, reality.  We discussed if I could get off work a little early Friday afternoon, and I thought I could.  We decided to fly to Atlanta, drive to Birmingham, stay in Birmingham, drive to Tuscaloosa Saturday morning, fly out of Atlanta on Sunday.  We got flights and hotel reservations, he reserved a rental car, and before I knew it we were headed on our first weekend getaway together.  I was excited...I loved the idea that this actually happens and that spontaneity isn't dead.

Friday it was a little hard to concentrate at work, our flight left at 4:50 from Houston and I was busy all morning and early afternoon.  He got stuck late in a meeting and didn't end up at the airport till close to 4:20...we rushed to the departing gate and finally ended up on the plane.  We were off and we were exhausted.  Good conversation and a few beers on the plane made the flight seem like it was quite short and before I knew it we were in Atlanta.  Birmingham is about 150  miles from Atlanta, so we picked up the car and off we drove to Alabama.  Once we found the hotel we drove to a cute little bar in downtown Birmingham where the LSU-Birmingham chapter was having a pregame get together.  It was so much fun, beads and Mardi Gras music, the beer they were serving was brewed in New Orleans.  We had gumbo and a few beers before heading back to the hotel for some much needed rest.

The next morning I was awoken at 6:30 am to a very excited and eager LSU fan.  He had been up since 5 am and run 3 miles, gone to Walgreens (neither one of us brought toothpaste), visited the breakfast buffet and secured both of us some coffee, plus planned the route we were taking to the game.  It was actually quite cute...very reminiscent of a kid waiting for Christmas morning...so excited he could barely sit still.  I showered and got dressed in my all too neutral black tank top and khaki pants (I did sport a small Geaux Tigers pin on my hoodie), and jumped in the car to an LSU CD playing the fight song and other band collections I would be hearing later that afternoon.  We made it to Tuscaloosa and got breakfast and found a place to park.  The day was unbelievably beautiful...crisp and clear without a cloud in the sky, little humidity and no wind.  A perfect day to watch football, make new friends, and eat lots of great food.  ESPN College GameDay was there along with thousands of fans from both schools.  Eveyone was nice and cordial with good-spirited taunting and name-calling. 

Dane and I walked around and took in the sights.  There is a group of guys who dress up for one away game a year as blinged out pimps...they are hilarious...all from LSU, these guys of at least 30+ walk around in purple and gold suits with chalices for their pimp juice and a keg-a-rater full of Red Bull and Vodka, Crown and 7, and beer.  They also have music system with all the pimp music you could imagine...they were great and had an immediate following of young college girls trying to get free alcohol and looking for a great time.  The guys even have shirts made for the groupies that are pink tight spaghetti straps with their website on the back.  They had lots of attention and looked as if they were truly enjoying themselves. 

We finally met up with some other LSU fans at their tailgate and had more gumbo, jambalaya, great conversation, and plenty of beer.  This was my first experience with SEC football and it was an eye opener.  They love their booze.   At A&M we drink the night before and then after the game, but never before.  It is too damn hot and all of our games are in the middle of the afternoon.  Everyone in Tuscaloosa regardless of team ties was drinking and dancing and talking.  It was awesome.  Alot of the sites had big screen TV's with other games playing, people would come and ask for certain types of food or drink, there was great music and plenty of really cool people, and no one was mean or rude or unruly.  It was all playful jabbing at the other team, always followed by smiles and laughs.

The game started at 2:30 and we made our way to the stadium about 45 minutes before kickoff.  The game was awesome and LSU won in overtime.  After the game was over, Dane and I just sat in the stands for a while.  We listened to the band play and watched the very disappointed Bama fans leave with their washed out dreams on a National Championship.  We just sat and talked and watched and sat.  It was great...the perfect ending to a great day.  We took pics of the scoreboard and the band and the LSU fans...we marveled in the emotions that people can have for 56 guys who catch a pigskin...we just sat.  Finally, we made it back to the tailgate site and had some more food.  We stayed for about 2.5 more hours telling jokes and funny stories and getting to know people that Dane, until Saturday, had only talked to online about LSU football.  We were invited back whenever we liked, and even asked to tailgate with them at the Florida game next year.  Eventually we made it back to the hotel and fell into a dreamless slumber.

The next morning was a hectic mess and we almost got stuck in Atlanta for an additional day.  Luckily we made it back to Houston and spend the rest of  Sunday relaxing and eating orange sherbert.  He took today off and I had to work.  When we got home we napped for about 2.5 hours and missed the movie we had planned on seeing.  We rented the movie Crash, which I highly recommend if you have never seen it and then finally went to bed.  Here is where the trouble started...neither one of us could sleep.  We just tossed and turned and keep talking to each other about how bad it sucks not to be able to fall asleep.  Finally, after truly contemplating sticking hot pokers in my eyes, I fell asleep...after 3 am.  What finally did it...Dane reading to me about what else then LSU football.  It was very sweet and greatly appreciated.  I worked all day, came home and made a casserole for a pot luck tomorrow at work, showered, and now here I am.

Here I am...what a bold statement.  For the first time in a long time I am happy just for the moment.  I am living in this exact day and not concentrating on next week, month, or year.  It is wonderful...I am happy and my life is full in all aspects.  I am thankful...my cup runneth over.  I have no idea what has happened but I am not scared, I am just letting everything happen.  I still have to remind myself on an every 2 or 3 day basis that it is okay to be happy, but I am learning to deal.  I have great friends that give me all the support I need and who I know regardless of what the future holds will be there every step of the way.  I feel lucky and full and happy and giddy and not afraid of tomorrow. 

It is a good feeling.

It is just after midnight here in Houston, or rather Conroe, which is 30 miles north of Houston.  I have just gotten home from picking my sister up from my other sister's house.  They left Houston this morning at 4 am and arrived in The Woodlands at around 6 pm tonight.  Yes, that is right 12 hours to go 40 miles.  It is truly unbelievable what I saw and what they went through.  They called and when they could get through would just sit on the phone with pleas for help or an end to this nightmare.  They were hot and couldn't run their AC because they were scared they would run out of gas.  They finally jumped off the freeway and took some side roads until they found a gas station and a bathroom.  It was 97' here today and a heat index of over 105'.  They were moving about 2-3 miles per hour.  As they said, we would go one car length and then stop for about 15 minutes and then one car length again. 

M. my youngest sister isn't married and just wanted to come home, rather than stay with my other married sister and her husband.  After all she had been through I could not not go get her.  So my mom and I set out about 8 pm tonight to go get her.  We live close to I45 which has been made a contraflow interstate for the evacuation.  There are over 1.8 million people who are trying to leave the Gulf Coast area and South Houston.  As you can imagine the traffic is fucking unbelievable.  It is like one huge parking lot.  What I saw though brought me to tears...my mom too.  There are hundreds of cars pulled over on the side of the highway, children crying, and parents trying to comfort them.  They don't know where they are going and when or if they will ever get there.  They are beginning to appear hopeless and the look of desperation in their eyes is unfathomable.  They are even starting shelters in this area, which is still in the projected hurricane path, but anywhere is better than your car on the side of the road when this monster hits. All of our hotels are full.  None of our gas stations have any gas...for hundreds of miles.  Many people have either run out of gas or worse their car has overheated.  The Texas National Guard has been sent over from NOLA and are filling tanks as we speak.  They are setting up roadside emergency stations and rest stops where motorists can fill up their cars with gas and get something to eat and drink.  Thank God.  Many of these people have been driving on what is quickly approaching 24 hours.  They are tired and frustrated and scared and angry and just plain dumbfounded.  I wish I could have taken pictures to show you how utterly hopeless the situation is.  It broke my heart...I wanted to bring all of them back to my house, but I don't even know if my house will be that safe.  I wanted to bring them gas, but we don't have any.  I just wanted to help, but all I could do was keep on driving. 

We have two guests staying with us from the coastal region and possible a third on the way.  One we don't know at all but came with a friend of my mom's.  Actually he called and was lost and about out of gas.  He was desperate.  He started traveling at 2 am this morning and in 16 hours made it 18 miles...arghhh.  He is now thankfully asleep upstairs. 

So luckily, we got M. and because we are from the area took some back roads home and it only took us about 1.5 hours to go the same distance that usually takes about 20 minutes.  She is exhausted and just so glad to be home safely.  Below are the closest pics I could find to show you the complete chaos.

 

This is what many of the houses on Galveston island and surrounding coastal areas have done. 

The shelves are bare...no food, no water, no batteries, no candles, no flashlights, no canned goods.

I am scared.  I am afraid for my family and my friends.  I am worried about the only place I have ever called home. I lived here in 1983 when Hurricane Alicia came ashore.  I was 8 years old and she was a CAT III.  I thought it was fun, we got out of school, we had no electricity, and I played with my friends for 7 straight days.  There were trees on houses and massive flooding, but when you are 8 it isn't things you even know to worry about.  Being 30 is an entire different story.  I can't turn off the TV, I can't stop reading the weatherman blogs, I can't fathom that this is happening 2x in one month.  Two CAT IV or higher hurricanes have NEVER hit the US mainland in one year...and now we have 2 hitting withing 300 miles of one another.  This storm is a monster and very unpredictable.  All afternoon they have said that it looked like it was turning north and was going closer to TX/LA border and possibly causing great harm to many areas affected by Katrina including NOLA.  Tonight, she has stared a straight west movement which brings her mere miles east of Galveston.  Who knows...they say it won't be for sure until about 12-24 hours before landfall or sometime tomorrow am. 

I am also so frightened for my friend Nick who is in NOLA with the National Guard.  The last time I talked to him he was frustrated and tired and scared. I really hate politics.  I have never been interested in them and only recently have I begun to understand why.  I was raised in a relatively conservative town in Texas...I went to college at Texas A&M, a conservative college...I went to medical school in Des Moines, IA, again, a conservative midwest town...my parents are conservative...my grandparents were/are conservative...it is in my blood, I was born and raised a Republican.  For many years I never questioned my political affiliation, the majority of Texas is Republican and conservative, and it is all I knew.  I just completed my residency in Philadelphia, and now many things I took for granted I am now questioning.

I AM CONSERVATIVE, I AM A REPUBLICAN, I DO NOT SUPPORT OUR PRESIDENT 100%.

For many years I was Republican because my parents were Republican.  Heck, all my friends' parents are Republican, most of us didn't have much of a choice or the knowledge to question what we believed.  Contrary to popular belief, media is different here.  We hear the conservative side, the side that Bush is doing an amazing job and we should name our first born GEORGE WALKER.  He is one of us, his parents live in Houston, he was our Governor (and a decent one at that), his dad's library is at A&M, we have watched his daughter's grow-up....loyalty comes from alot more than political affliations here in the South.  To many of us (not necessarily me), he is part of our family...since his dad was in office we have watched him mature...we looked at him in times of crisis while he was Governor, and most of the time he came through for us, we remember when his daughters were born, even some remember his marriage...he is tried and true a Texan even though he wasn't born here...we have accepted him as one of our own.

I wish I could give you a glance into the mind set down here...it is so different than any liberal city on the East coast.  Many people don't read the paper or listen to the news...they get there information from the hair salon or the coffee shop or the diner or the gas station or their other friends who don't read the newspaper either.  They are not dumb or stupid...they are uninformed and yes, it is partially their fault.  They don't care, they don't want to change, because it is all they know or have ever known.  Their entire family is conservative and on election day they go to their voting places and check the Republican box at the top of the ballot, many times not even reading the names.  Sad, but true, many couldn't tell you who ran against Bush at the last election...they don't even know Kerry's name.  It is sad, but it is life in small town America in the South, especially here in Texas.  The attitude is completely different in any of your big cities...Houston, Dallas, San Antonio, and especially Austin...have more educated people and more liberal viewpoints.  They begin to question what has always been their lifestyle...the young travel to other places and read and educate themselves on other issues, and many of us change points of our affiliations.  I know I have.

Here is a perfect example...When I moved to Philadelphia I became friends with many Muslim doctors who are from the Mideast.  It was so interesting listening to their ideas and viewpoints.  They are from Syria and Lebanon and Algeria...they are the ones who get racially profiled in airports...they are great people and loyal friends.  My grandmother who is 80 years old learned that I had made new friends...then she found out they were Muslim...then she got nervous.  She actually told me, "Don't get involved with these men.  They are manipulative and beat their wives."  This statement is so wrong in so many ways...it is hard to blame her though...she was born and raised in Texas and has never lived outside of this state.  She has gone to the same church for over 30 years and was married to the same man for over 60 years.  She has WASPy friends and does not know any Muslims...she only knows what she hears on TV or reads.  She is uninformed and ignorant, not racist.  Second, to even listen to her say this infuriates me and at the same time makes me laugh, because none of us have ever know a Chrisitian man who beats his wife or is manipulative...it is only Muslim men...yeah, right.

I am one of the lucky ones.  I have had the opportunity to live other places...I have friends of all different nationalities, religions, and beliefs...I have been exposed to liberal viewpoints and been able to question my ideas as well as those of others without being chastisied.  I have learned that in Philadelphia, I would still be considered conservative, but here in Texas I am middle of the road.  I believe in Pro-Choice and stem cell research and helping the poor...I support the war and the troops....I believe we are making a difference in the MidEast...I AM UPSET WITH THE PRESIDENT'S REACTION TO HURRICANE KATRINA.  I do not believe he is a criminal or that he deserves to take all the blame...he screwed up, he should have reacted faster, he should have jumped into a car and drove himself down to NOLA to see firsthand before the relief effort got there.  I wanted to see him upset...I wanted to see him pacing the Oval Office waiting to hear that of HIS citizens were off the rooftops and that all the hospitals and nursing homes had been evacuated.  I wanted tears and hand-wringing because he was worried about the children and the families that were separated.  I wanted there to be a plan, at least a better plan than there was.  I want him to admit that HE, not anybody else, let his people down and that he is at least partially responsible for the large loss of life.  I wanted more of personal response, I wanted raw emotion, and I got none.  I got a President who made jokes about being drunk in NOLA and called the director of FEMA "Brownie".  I am disappointed in my President and his actions and I deserve answers.  I still support him, I am disappointed, I am mad, I am infuriated, I am sad, I can't stop watching the news, I am waiting for answers and I still haven't gotten any.

I am even more disappointed with the City of New Orleans.  They are a city who failed their own people...they let their fellow friends and families down.  When I was 7 years old, my family was vacationing in NOLA.  It is still one of my favorite family trips, we ate crawfish and beignets, we went to the museums and the voodoo shops.  We also looked at the levees and my dad 23 years ago said, "Amy, one day these levees are going to fail and the city of NO is going to flood.  The entire city will flood and all it is going to take is one big storm."  My father, 23 years ago, knew this...why wasn't something done.  I understand that the Army Corp of Engineers has been asking for years for money to fix the levees and each year Congress has given them less and less.  This pisses me off, because now after this, we have to look back and wonder what would have happened.  It makes me mad that none of the Presidents over the past 25 years have found it a high enough priority to make Congress give them more money.  It was that stupid train of thought that we know it can happen but it hasn't yet so we will test our luck for another year...our luck finally ran out.  So if the city of NO and the state of LA and my dad in TX knew that the levees were going to break then implement a damn plan.  Don't wait on the cavalry or the President, think for yourselves and develop a plan.  If you are not getting the response you need then find another way...save your own people and then take it up with the higher ups.  The mayor of NO is just as guilty as the Goveror of LA and the director of FEMA and the President of the United States.  He failed his own people...he could have developed a plan.  Stock pile supplies in the Superdome, implement your own plan, think for Well today finally happened and yes my emotions found me before I left the city.  I have cried and cried and my eyes will be puffy tomorrow.  I am sure you are suprised that I am actually posting but felt like I needed this to stay close for as long as possible.  

First, I want to thank both of you for a fabulous weekend.  It is just what I needed to leave the city with.  I have learned so much over the past two years and this weekend was an epitome of a lot of that learning.  It makes me feel better knowing that you have each other to take care of and I know that is enough to keep many people busy for many days. I know it is not the city that has any of the memories but I BELIEVE that the past 3 years could be my happiest years in my grown up life.  I am becoming comfortable in my own skin finally and it feels great.  I am not scared of my opinions or  my differences but rather cherish them and love the fact that these things make me different.

Second, I would have stayed in Philly in a second if deep down I felt it was the right thing.  Unfortunately, in my heart I know I belong in Texas or at least the South.  I have a lot of people to teach a bunch of things too, especially my family and close friends who are ultra conservative.  I know that you, my friends, will find me there and love me no matter where I am.  That is another great feeling.

So today is the day...my movers come to pack away all my stuff and then trek off with it to Texas.  Of course, they were supposed to be here by 3:00 and now it is almost 5 and no movers, but none-the-less they are on the Turnpike (or said the man who just called).  It is really weird sitting in a house with all of your belongings packed away neatly in little brown boxes.  It makes me realize that it wouldn't be very fun to go through life without certain possessions to remind you who you are and where you came from.  By this I mean...one of my favorite pics is of my sisters and I on the beach about 22-23 years ago.  We are all wearing matching bathing suits and have our hair in pigtails, but the smiles we have on our face are so genuine...we had little worries, but had no clue how good we had it.  That pic brings back so many good memories of the beach with my grandparents and us being young.  Now that I worry about everything it does me good to remember those times of mindless childhood where the days consisted of playing with your friends, riding your bike, and fighting over who had the best Barbie.  That pic is now residing carefully packed in newspaper in a brown box ready for yet another adventure.

My subject today brings me to a very unsettling feeling I have been experiencing lately...EMOTIONLESS.  I have been so emotional for the past few weeks, crying over nothing and having mood swings that some would think require meds to normalize the storm.  Recently, I have become void of emotion...not completely happy and not sad but indifferent.  I think it is a really well-devised defense mechanism allowing me to exist everyday without breaking down and not being able to coherently go on.  Maybe it comes from somewhere deep inside that has existed in all of us for eternity but we are only able to tap into during certain situations in our life. 

I said goodbye to our office staff today and my attendings.  I truly believed I would bawl my eyes out and leave there a blubbering idiot...but instead I said my goodbyes gave my hugs and kisses and walked out of the building without having shed a tear.  It is not that I am not sad but I can not find my emotions at the moment.  I am sure they are there somewhere, but come on, a few tears would be nice.  I am so scared I will leave here and not be able to express to certain people how much they mean to me and how much I have appreciated their love and support over the past 3 years. Hopefully, most of these people already know how I feel, but I would like to mention it to them again.  I have done a lot of growing while here in Philly and have so many to thank for the new and improved me.

I am also scared that 2 months from now some little thing is going to set off a string of emotions that I won't be able to control.  You know those stupid things that really don't matter that much in life but for so reason at that exact moment it seems like the end of the world.  Then I will be back in Texas and my mom or sisters won't be able to relate and again, I will feel alone.  So I am going to try and find my emotions over the next few days, maybe they are hiding under my bed and when the movers come today they will pop out and surprise me.  Since I am no longer required at work I will have plenty of time to walk around the city and soak up some of the "philliness" before I depart for the 28 hour drive to Texas.  If I don't find me emotions before then I am sure they will find a little corner to hide in my car to go home with me.

So it is so damn funny how life goes sometimes.  Things that you are actually dreading become better just by chance.  Yes, probably rambling...but life right now is going okay...little skeptical about admitting that because then I get nervous that it will take a turn for the worse.  My dear friends keep reminding me to live in the moment, be happy, and all that other good shit.  Fortunately, I think they are right and it is nice to be reminded of this on a somewhat daily basis.

My movers come next Monday or Tuesday and then I am off on the 5th.  I have a great friend who has actually volunteered to drive back to Texas with me...it is so nice of her and makes me much less nervous about the ride.  I don't think Tex will appreciate it much though because he just got stuck in the back...oh well.

It still hasn't sunk in yet that I am leaving.  Yes, there are boxes all over my house and all my personal pics and favorite things are currently residing in a brown box, but my mind refuses to grasp the concept.  I believe this is partly my fault for refusing to think about, but also I have an overwhelming sense of peace and I sure didn't create that.  Maybe this is what is supposed to be happening...in all aspects I am just along for the ride.

I woke up this morning and for the first time in years I didn't think..oh, I have to go study (actually I really did think that but then reminded myself I didn't have to).  So, I rolled over and curled back up under my blanket and slept for another hour.  It was great, that restful sleep where you forget about all your problems and just relax.  I then got up, made a pot of coffee and just sat on my couch.  I just sat there for a long time and didn't do anything.  I didn't even get myself a cup of coffee.  I just sat and stared and thought.  In a way, I think I was realizing that this is the start of a turning point.  For the first time, I was letting myself believe in change (the good and bad parts).  I started thinking of so many things...and believe it or not, they weren't the sad, tearful, cry-your-eyes-out thoughts, but rather serene thoughts about life.  For about 2 hours, I was honestly okay with what is about to happen...then I started to remember the sucky parts of moving and didn't feel so good after all.

But for those 2 hours I felt peaceful.

Yesterday, after finishing the boards (BTW:the 2nd part truly rocked my world...they might be laughing at my answers)I went to hang out with one of my co-residents.  He is getting married next weekend.  We had a celebratory drink and then out for sushi.  His fiancee and her sister came with us.  When we got to the restaurant they escorted us straight to a table and we all sat down.  Not two minutes later the waiter arrives with 4 champagne glasses and a bottle of Korbel.  My friend and I are amazed because we have no clue any of this is happening.  His fiancee then precedes to toast us for finishing up with residency and the boards.  She then looks at me and adds, "We would also like to toast you for your friendship over the past 3 years, we believe you have added a lot of love not only to us, but all you have met."  My mouth preceded to hit the table and my eyes teared up.  It was a very special moment...one that I was not at all expecting.  It made me understand...I'm not sure what I now understand, but I understand.  Dinner was great and then I drove home. 

On the way home I began to reflect on the people I have met while here in Philly.  
Amazing people...who have taught me more than I ever dreamed possible.  Many things have happened to me while I was here.  I learned that I am beautiful (yes, someone actually told me that), that there are people out there who are truly conquering their dark monsters, that true friends don't care...they just sit by and hold your hand, that love is unconditionable, that diversity is one of God's greatest gifts, and I am beginning to remember that I do deserve to be happy.  I still feel happy, not run around and jump on the couch like Tom Cruise happy, but nonetheless happy.  Maybe it's not happy, maybe I have some sort of peace, or maybe, just maybe I am beginning to understand.

I am feeling a little relieved right now, still a bit nervous, but much better than last night.  Today I finished part 1 of my national certification and tomorrow I will finish part 2.  I have no idea how I did and won't know until August, but boy does it feel good to be 1/2 done.  Of course, I am now second guessing every answer I gave, and am pretty sure I failed but in the end all that matters is that I am done (nice long run-on sentence).  Now, the new question is Do I study tonight?  I probably will but have been warned against it.

Actually right at this very moment I am happy.  Genuinely happy and I have no idea why.  It feels nice, maybe it will stay for a few days.

I am rambling, but my thoughts aren't even making sense in my own head...

Broody storks snatch golf balls and try to hatch them
By Bojan Pancevski in Neumuenster
(Filed: 22/05/2005)

A pair of storks that decided to nest on the middle of a German golf course were so keen to become parents that they stole balls from players and tried to hatch them. They took so many balls that one nest, on the fourth green, overflowed and they built a second at the seventh hole for their haul.

Although their chances of parenthood appeared remote, the birds were regarded as a biological sensation by German nature authorities. Breaking with tradition, they had decided to nest on the ground rather than on top of a chimney.

 
Storks next to the golf course

Curious crowds flocked to see them at Golf Park Krogaspe near Neumuenster and last week a conservation group asked the club's British owner, Chris Parker, if the storks could incubate an egg left abandoned after the parents were killed. The egg was successfully infiltrated among the balls the chick is expected to hatch next week to be looked after by its surrogate parents - nicknamed Storki and Staki.

"I was happy to agree, especially if it stopped them stealing golf balls in the middle of play," said Mr Parker, 53.

He has erected a barrier to protect the storks, which first took up residence two weeks ago. "At first we tried to chase them away, as we feared that they might get hit by a golf ball, but they proved very stubborn - and less timid by the day.

"We couldn't believe it when we saw the nest filled with stolen balls. We contacted the German Nature Preservation Association and at first they didn't believe us. When they came to see, there was a lot of excitement."

Georg Fiedler, of the association, said: "Between 1894 and 1997 only 16 stork couples in the whole of Europe have been reported to have had nests on the ground."

Mr Fiedler, who has studied storks for 34 years, thinks that the birds might have lost their own nest, possibly to another pair. "The breeding season lasts a short time," he said. "I believe that, driven by a remarkable parental urge, they nested on the green and tried to hatch golf balls. They obviously feel they bear a sufficient resemblance to stork eggs even though they are only about half the size."

Mr Parker, a former golf professional in Britain who moved to Germany in 1989 for a teaching job, said that storks were frequent visitors to the club. "They fly over the course and occasionally come down to feed as the grass is short and they can hunt their mice and frogs easier.

"Two weeks ago these storks landed on the green and started building nests. They settled by the 200-metre mark on the driving range, a fairly remote area where they don't get disturbed."

The chance for the storks to adopt a chick came when three eggs were salvaged from a nest whose parent birds apparently flew into overhead electricity cables.

Two artificially hatched eggs have already produced healthy birds and Mr Parker's storks are in loco parentis of the third.

"We put the egg in their nest, right next to the golf balls," said Mr Fielder. "The storks were watching carefully from a distance, then came back as we left and inspected the novelty with great caution.

"I was worried that the birds might become irritated and damage the egg, but after a few minutes it was obvious that they had fully accepted it as their own. The offspring is due in about four days."

Should the egg hatch successfully, the storks are likely to stay at the golf course for up to nine weeks while they teach the fledgling to fly.

Reports say the full-grown lioness came across the oryx two weeks ago in the Samburu Game Reserve, scaring off its mother.

Instead of then attacking the defenceless calf, the lioness adopted the baby, protecting it from other predators, including a leopard.

Extraordinarily, the lioness still allowed the mother oryx occasionally to come and feed her calf before chasing her away. But the rule of the wild ultimately prevailed on Sunday when a male lion attacked and killed the baby oryx while the lioness was sleeping.

'Special instinct'

"This is either an extraordinary case of maternal instinct or simply the eighth wonder of the world," local Herman Mwasaghu told The Nation newspaper.


What is baffling is why the relationship has lasted so long

Wildlife expert Vincent Kapeen
Mr Mwasaghu was one of the first to spot the unlikely pair, which proved a powerful draw for tourists and game workers alike.

The lioness would lie down to rest in the afternoon and its unlikely charge would curl up beside her.

Wildlife expert Vincent Kapeen said he thought the lioness spared the oryx "because animals have a special instinct to care for the young".

"What is baffling is why the relationship has lasted so long," he was quoted as saying.

Sad ending

According to the AFP news agency, the sad end to the story came on Sunday when the lioness led the oryx to the river to drink.

Weakened by two weeks of looking after her adopted baby, she fell asleep, failing to notice a hungry male lion in the area.

The oryx was no more. Patrick Muriungi, a receptionist at Samburu Lodge, told AFP the lioness was grief-stricken when she awoke to realise what had happened.

"She was very angry. She went around the lion about 10 times roaring, and then the lioness disappeared," he was quoted as saying.

She has not been seen since.
